item.title: Parliament of Sri Lanka Is Dissolved by President
item.description: President Maithripala Sirisena dissolved the Parliament loyal to his predecessor and called new elections in an attempt to consolidate power and carry out his promise of reforms.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Mass Funeral Held in Kuwait for 27 Killed in Bombing
item.description: The police said they were interrogating a number of people with possible links to the attack, which was claimed by an affiliate of the Islamic State group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Thousands attended rites in Kuwait City on Saturday for victims of a suicide bombing that occurred during Friday Prayer.

item.title: Suspect in Attack in France Had Ties to Radical Islamist
item.description: Yassine Salhi, who the authorities say decapitated his boss before setting off an explosion at a chemical plant on Friday, belonged to the circle around a radical Islamist.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Greek Debt Crisis Intensifies as Extension Request Is Denied
item.description: European officials rejected Greece’s request to extend its bailout program so voters could decide whether to accept aid under terms the government opposes.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: People lined up Saturday at an Athens bank. Eurozone finance ministers met in Brussels, trying to salvage a Greek bailout plan.

item.title: ISIS and the Lonely Young American
item.description: For months, Alex had been growing closer to a new group of friends online – the kindest she had ever had – who were teaching her what it meant to be a Muslim.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It gets lonely here,” Alex, 23, said of living with her grandparents. She found comfort in a group of online friends who guided her to convert to Islam.

item.title: Kerry, in Vienna, Begins Effort to Complete Nuclear Accord With Iran
item.description: The secretary of state faced a deadline that American officials have almost conceded that the parties will not meet.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, and Wendy R. Sherman, the under secretary for political affairs, in Vienna on Saturday.

item.title: Once a Beloved French Symbol, a Ship Now Rusts Into Oblivion
item.description: Jacques Cousteau’s famed research vessel has languished in a coastal French warehouse as a monetary dispute over its restoration and future drags on.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The prow of Jacques Cousteau’s ship, the Calypso, in a repair hangar in the port town of Concarneau on the western coast of France. Restoration work ended in 2009 in a dispute over money.

item.title: On ISIS’ Terms: Courting a Young American
item.description: For months, Alex had been growing closer to a new group of friends online – the kindest she had ever had – who were teaching her what it meant to be a Muslim.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It gets lonely here,” Alex, 23, said of living with her grandparents. She found comfort in a group of online friends who guided her to convert to Islam.

item.title: Gunman Pursued Tourists in Slaughter at a Tunisian Beach Hotel
item.description: The killer pursued sunbathers from the beach to the pool and eventually to the administration offices of the Imperial Marhaba Hotel, slaying 39 people and wounding 38 others.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL and FARAH SAMTI
item.media:description: A woman prepared to lay flowers at the beach next to the Imperial Marhaba Hotel, where 39 people were killed on Friday.

item.title: Yevgeny Primakov, Former Premier of Russia, Dies at 85
item.description: A former prime minister and spymaster, Mr. Primakov was also the Kremlin’s top expert on Middle Eastern affairs.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Yevgeny M. Primakov, right, with former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 2012.

item.title: Greek Prime Minister Calls for Referendum on Bailout Terms
item.description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras accused creditors of presenting Greece with unfair terms and called on citizens to decide how to respond.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Alexis Tsipras, Greece’s prime minister, right, with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France, left, in Brussels on Friday.

item.title: Terrorist Attacks in France, Tunisia and Kuwait Kill Dozens
item.description: An American-owned plant was attacked in France, a beach resort was struck in Tunisia, and ISIS claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing at a Kuwait mosque.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: The Imam Sadiq Mosque in Kuwait City after a suicide bomber killed at least 25 Shiite worshipers during Friday Prayer.

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Diplomat Rejects U.N. Tribunal on Malaysian Jet Shot Down in Ukraine
item.description: A senior Russian official rejected calls Friday for the establishment of a United Nations tribunal to try those responsible for shooting down a Malaysia Airlines flight in eastern Ukraine last year.
item.dc:creator: AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Nepal: Rough Terrain and Bad Weather Led to Helicopter Crash, Report Says
item.description: The crash of a United States Marines helicopter in Nepal that killed 13 people in May was caused by bad weather and the geography of the region, the Nepalese Army said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: World Briefing: Kosovo: Parliament Votes Against Court to Prosecute Crimes in ’90s War
item.description: Kosovo’s Parliament voted Friday not to approve constitutional amendments that would have allowed the establishment of a special court to prosecute war crimes.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Board of State Oil Company Is Dissolved After Corruption Scandal
item.description: Nigeria’s new president, Muhammadu Buhari, on Friday dissolved the board of the state oil company from which billions of dollars is reported to be missing.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Tunisia Attack Kills at Least 39 at Beach Resort Hotel
item.description: Many of the victims were foreigners, in the second major terrorist attack on Tunisia’s tourism industry in a little more than three months.
item.dc:creator: FARAH SAMTI and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: French Authorities Hold Suspect in Beheading and Explosion at Chemical Plant
item.description: President François Hollande said a beheaded body had been found at the American-operated factory, and that the assailant had been arrested and identified.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Police investigators outside the Air Products chemical plant in St.-Quentin-Fallavier, where an attacker decapitated a person on Friday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Working Within the System to Disrupt Brazilian Politics
item.description: Roberto Mangabeira Unger, a Harvard philosopher born in Brazil and raised in Manhattan, has settled into a career as an appointed public figure charged with fostering long-term thinking about Brazil.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Marizilda Cruppe for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s better to have a voice within the state than to have a voice outside, but it’s better to have a voice outside the state than to have no voice within the state.” —Roberto Mangabeira Unger

item.title: Mass Killings by ISIS Fighters in Syrian Kurdish Town
item.description: Islamic State fighters who sneaked into the Syrian Kurdish town of Kobani on the Turkish border killed more than 150 people there and in nearby villages.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
